title: 8.4 Your worst nightmare - b34
description: Deze les valt onder de arrangeerbare leerlijn van de Stercollecties voor Engels voor vmbo beroepsgerichte leerweg, leerjaar 3 en 4. Dit is thema 8 'Dreams'. Het onderwerp van deze les is: Your worst nightmare. Deze les staat in het teken van nachtmerries of nare dromen en dutjes (naps). De onregelmatige werkwoorden in deze les zijn: to wear, to win en to write. In de grammaticaopdracht wordt de 'conditionals' behandeld.

items.content:
Het onderwerp van dit blokuur is nachtmerries.

  • Maak groepjes van drie of vier leerlingen.

Bespreek de volgende vragen in jouw groepje:

  • Waar denk je aan bij het woord: "nachtmerrie"?
  • Wat voor enge dingen kunnen er voorkomen in een droom?


Bekijk hieronder de stappen die je gaat zetten.

Reasons you need a nap

You are going to listen to a podcast about sleep.

  • Listen to the podcast and do assignment 1.
  • Read the questions.
  • Listen again to the introduction of the podcast (until 1.44) and do assignment 2 and 3.

Assignment 1

Listen to the podcast and answer the questions on your own, then discuss the answers in your group.

  • How many people do you hear in the introduction of this podcast?
  • What does Dr. Matthew Walker say about sleep?

Questions

  1. How much time of our lives do we spend sleeping?
  2. Where does Lisa Hurst-Cairns come from?
  3. What is the problem of Will Parkhurst?
  4. What is the profession of Raquel Zic?

prompt.body: How much time of our lives do we spend sleeping?
What is the problem of Will Parkhurst?
What is the profession of Raquel Zic?

content.body:
Luister nog een keer naar het gesprek en sleep de ontbrekende zinsdelen naar de juiste plek.

RACHEL MARTIN, HOST: We spend one-third of our lives sleeping. That's more time than we spend doing anything else, but we still don't know very much . So today, we're trying to answer some pretty basic yet complicated questions: Why do we sleep? Can we live without it, and how can we get more? Because let's face it, there are a out there who are not exactly sleeping soundly.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC, CLOCK TICKING)

LISA HURST-CAIRNS: You're looking at your clock and it's - oh, 2:20, 2:30, 2:40; and you're doing the math. Now I've got three hours, or , to sleep, and I'm going to be dead tired in the morning.

WILL PARKHURST: I started noticing in the morning that there'd be like, pretty much just crumbs on the ground next to my bed, and I'd have food that I did not remember ever bringing to bed with me.

RAQUEL ZIC: I usually take Benadryl and . To get up at 2:30 in the morning, it's kind of a necessary evil.

PARKHURST: So I started off with a lot of ice cream. Cereal's pretty common. Pretzels, stuff like that; chips, crackers. For a while, I a bunch of granola in my sleep.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

HURST-CAIRNS: For so many years, I was like, fighting this, you know, inability . So every night, waking up and just kind of going, oh, no. Now, I only have like, four more hours; and I've got to do this and this and this the next day - and really, just getting in this like, anxious spiral.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC, CLOCK TICKING)

MARTIN: That was Lisa Hurst-Cairns, from Minneapolis; Will Parkhurst, a sleep eater from Austin, Texas; and ambulance driver Raquel Zic, who has to wake up at 2:30 a.m.

about sleep
lot of us
four hours
next to my bed
melatonin
was eating
to stay asleep
an insomniac

items.content:
Dreams

You are going to read a text about a person who tells us about his experience with dreams.

  • Read the text and do assignment 1.
  • Read the text again and do assigment 2.

Assignment 1

Read the text and answer the question on your own, then discuss the answer in your group.

  • What examples of what might happen in dreams does the author give in this text?

Dreams
Now and again I have had horrible dreams, but not enough of them to make me lose my delight in dreams.
To begin with, I like the idea of dreaming, of going to bed and lying still and then, by some queer magic, wandering into another kind of existence.
As a child I could never understand why grown-ups took dreaming so calmly when they could make such a fuss about any holiday. This still puzzles me. I am mystified by people who say they never dream and appear to have no interest in the subject.
It is much more astonishing than if they said they never went out for a walk. Most people -- or at least most Western Europeans -- do not seem to accept dreaming as part of their lives. They appear to see it as an irritating little habit, like sneezing or yawning.
I have never understood this. My dream life does not seem as important as my waking life, if only because there is far less of it, but to me it is important. As if there were at least two extra continents added to the world, and lightning excursions running to them at any moment between midnight and breakfast.

Then again, the dream life, though queer and bewildering and unsatisfactory in many respects, has its own advantages. The dead are there, smiling and talking. The past is there, sometimes all broken and confused but occasionally as fresh as a daisy. And perhaps, as Mr. Dunne tells us, the future is there too, winking at us. This dream life is often overshadowed by huge mysterious anxieties, with luggage that cannot be packed and trains that refuse to be caught: and both persons and scenes there are not as dependable and solid as they are in waking life, so that Brown and Smith merge into one person while Robinson splits into two, and there are thick woods outside the bathroom door and the dining room is somehow part of a theatre balcony: and there are moments of desolation or terror in the dream world that are worse than anything we have known under the sun.

Yet this other life has its interests, its gaieties, its satisfactions, and, at certain rare intervals, a serene glow or a sudden ecstasy, like glimpses of another form of existence altogether, that we cannot match with open eyes. Daft or wise, terrible or exquisite, it is a further helping of experience, a bonus after dark, another slice of life cut differently, for which, it seems to me, we are never sufficiently grateful. Only a dream ! Why only ? It was there, and you had it. "If there were dreams to sell," Beddoes inquires, "what would you buy ?" I cannot say offhand, but certainly rather more than I could afford.

Bron: www.englishdaily626.com

He is puzzled by what they claim.

seem to regard dreaming as an irritating habit.

prompt.body:

To the writer dreaming ...

content.body: is like sneezing and yawning, but more pleasurable.
opens up a whole new world of experience for him.

prompt.body:

The "lightning excursions" refer to the writer's ...

Choose the right answer.

Choose the right answer.

We may have a dream experience "that we cannot match with open eyes". This means that the dream experience

content.body: is not like any experience in real life.
cannot be understood when we are awake.

prompt.body:
Choose the right answer.

The writer's answer to the question at the end of the extract shows that he ...

content.body: would love to be able to dream more.
would like to have fewer dreams.
does not mind whether he dreams more often or less.

prompt.body:
Choose the right answer.

Which statement about dreams is not made by the writer?

content.body: Dreams can be bewildering at times.
Dreams are more important than our waking life.

items.content:
Bestudeer de woordenlijst.

Woordenlijst Your worst nightmare


Tip!
Er zijn verschillende manieren om woordjes te leren.
Je kunt de woorden hardop voorlezen of overschrijven.
Het belangrijkste is dat je dit niet te lang achter elkaar doet, want dan leer je niets meer.
In twee keer 10 minuten leer je meer dan in een half uur.

Irregular Verbs

Bestudeer de volgende drie irregular verbs (onregelmatige werkwoorden):

  • to wear
  • to win
  • to write

content.body:
Sleep de woorden naar de juiste plaats in de tabel.

After decades of sleep research we still don't know everything.

Na tientallen jaren weten we nog steeds niet alles.

Without sleep brain and body functions start to deteriorate.

Zonder slaap het functioneren van de hersenen en het lichaam.

Alcohol is disruptive to sleep.

Alcohol de slaap.

Sometimes I have horrible dreams.

Soms heb ik dromen.

Some people make a fuss about their dreams.

Sommige mensen hun dromen.

Last night I had an astonishing dream.

Gisteren had ik een droom.

The future is winking at us.

De toekomst .

This dream life is overshadowed by huge mysterious anxieties.

Dit droomleven wordt overschaduwd door enorme .

I don't like dreams of desolation and terror.

Ik hou niet van dromen over en verschrikking.

I prefer dreams with a serene glow.

Ik geef de voorkeur aan dromen met .

  2. Pulling the all-nighter is a very bad idea.
  3. Two people merge into one person.
  4. Last night I had an astonishing dream.
  5. Some people make a fuss about their dreams.
  6. A person who doesn't sleep is an insomniac .

items.content:
Conditionals

In deze les behandelen we (nogmaals) de Conditionals.

  • Bekijk de uitleg in de kennisbank.
  • Maak daarna de opdracht.
Conditionals

content.body:
Vul de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in. Gebruik de first of second conditional.

(to do) - If you come with me, I the shopping with you.

Vul de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in. Gebruik de first of second conditional.

(to help) - Walter his mother if she reads him a story this evening.

Vul de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in. Gebruik de first of second conditional.

(to rain) - If it , I will stay at home.

Vul de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in. Gebruik de first of second conditional.

(to be) - Our teacher happy if we learn the poem by heart.

Vul de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in. Gebruik de first of second conditional.

(to have) - If they enough money, they would buy a new car.

Vul de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in. Gebruik de first of second conditional.

(to pass) - We the exam if we studied harder.

Vul de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in. Gebruik de first of second conditional.

(to repair) - If Pat his bike, he could go on a bicycle tour with us.

Vul de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in. Gebruik de first of second conditional.

(to get) - She 100 pounds if she sold this old shelf.

Vul de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in. Gebruik de first of second conditional.

(to be) - If I you, I would invite Jack to the party.

Vul de juiste vorm van het werkwoord in. Gebruik de first of second conditional.

(to be) - If the weather fine, the children can walk to school.

Sleep de juiste werkwoordsvorm in de zin.

  1. (to come) - I early if you want.
  2. (to be) - They'will go to the party if they invited.
  3. (to get) - She will stay in London if she a job.
  4. (not to pass) - He won't get a better job if he that exam.
  5. (to buy) - I a new dress if I have enough money.
  6. (to buy) - She will cook dinner if you the ingredients.
  7. (to go) - They on holiday if they have time.
  8. (to be) - We late if we don't hurry.
  9. (to rain) - She will take a taxi if it .
  10. (not to go) - I if you don't come with me.

Sleep de juiste werkwoordsvorm in de zin.

  1. (to be) - She happier if she had more friends.
  2. (to decide) - We would buy a house if we to stay here.
  3. (to have) - They more money if they didn't buy so many clothes.
  4. (to come) - We to dinner if we had time.
  5. (to know) - She would call him if she his number.
  6. (to go) - They to Spain on holiday if they liked hot weather.
  7. (to study) - She would pass the exam if she more.
  8. (to be) - I would marry someone famous if I a movie star.
  9. (to buy) - We would never be late again if we a new car.
  10. (to lose) - You weight if you ate less.

items.content:
Talking about dreams - part 4

Discuss the questions in your group:

  1. Do you believe that dreams can help us solve our problems?
  2. Do you try to understand the meanings of your dreams?
  3. Have you ever had the same dream more than once?
  4. Describe a nightmare that you remember.
  5. Have you ever experienced insomnia?
  6. If you could have an operation that would allow you to get only two hours of sleep each night, would you have it? Why or why not?

Nightmares

Je hebt de laatste tijd nogal vaak nachtmerries. Je vraagt hierover advies aan je penvriend(in).

  • Maak de schrijfopdracht eerst alleen, daarna vergelijk je jouw e-mail met die van je groepsgenoten.
  • Schrijf een e-mail met je groepje en lever deze in bij je docent.

Je gaat een e-mail schrijven aan je penvriend(in) in Engeland.

Verwerk de volgende punten:

  • Bedenk een naam voor je penvriend(in).
  • Groet je penvriend(in).
  • Vertel dat je de laatste tijd veel nachtmerries hebt.
  • Vertel waar je over droomt. (zelf verzinnen, het hoeft niet waar te zijn)
  • Vertel waar je denkt dat het door komt.
  • Vraag je penvriend(in) om advies.
  • Schrijf een passend slot.
  • Schrijf je naam onder de e-mail.

Open het werkbestand in google docs: 8.4 Your worst nightmare - An email.
Maak een kopie van het werkblad in je eigen omgeving (Bestand - Een kopie maken...) of download het werkblad (Bestand - Downloaden als).

Vul het schema in en beantwoord de vragen onder het schema.

  • Zijn er nog dingen die je niet helemaal begrijpt? Wat ga je daaraan doen?
  • Wat moet ik nog aan mijn docent vragen?

Just a dream

Je gaat luisteren naar het liedje Just a dream van Nelly.

Bekijk de video.
